text: Patient: Yeah. I feel good. Doctor: I just, uh, that is frustrating. I was hoping they would do something to help. Patient: Well, I can always go somewhere else, but you know how that goes. text: Patient: So, that’s your immune system. Doctor: That’s the immune system. Patient: So, what happens in between, does that weaken your immune system or? Doctor: No, it actually if anything strengthens. Patient: I mean while it’s out. Doctor: Oh, no. We don’t take everything out. We just take a few things out. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Oh, man, no, we don’t take out anywhere close to your entire blood volume. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s just like this much but to do that they have to sort of strain for the right cells. That’s why you’re hooked up to this machine that they have for like two and a half three hours. So, I always say, you know, bring something to read. They play movies. If you have to pee a lot, you bring a urinal so you don’t have to get up because if nurses will start screaming if you move and um there’s two ways. Like you have pretty good veins so um most of the time they can just do it straight from your veins. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They’ll tell us whether that’s possible. A bunch of other people you need a port for six weeks where they actually put it in your arm or your chest and they remove the stuff, you know, out and then when we’re done we pull it out. Now, go like this and you know that your veins are there. They’re not spectacular veins but I don’t think they’re terrible veins. So, it’s like three hours for us to do that procedure and then when you get it reinfused back on a Thursday this stuff comes back in a bag and you get it through Patient: mm hmm.

text: Patient: Thank you. Doctor: I had to figure out what was gonna on with your lungs. Healthcare Professional: Hi. Doctor: I have a student in here um because I think we gotta work up why your lungs have these areas that don’t seem right. That seems to be your, your thing, every time I see you we’ve got the prostate, oh no we’ve got a lymph node. You know that kind of thing. Um I’m still gonna send you back to the radiation doctor because he may still want to do radiation. You know you’re already on the shot and the next one is in March. But we gotta figure out what’s going on with your lungs. It’s showing some new things in there that may or may not be something that’s cancer. It may not be cancer. I have no idea. Patient: They says it’s nodules or something. Doctor: Exactly. You know nodules are literally white little spots in your lungs. Who knows what that is? It could be a thousand things. Patient: Yeah well I had the flu and it was pneumonia the same time about three years ago. Doctor: Umm. I don’t know if that’s what it is, but guess what. I’m gonna send you to this good doctor. Dr. S____. He’s right in this clinic also and he’s gonna check you out. He’s probably gonna um make some recommendations about what to do for us to figure this out. But I think that’s important too. Now the good part is you’re already getting the shots. Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: And you know your PSA was coming down just from doing that. That part’s great but I don’t want to miss all the little details. I want to be right on top of this. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Any questions?

But, but, at a minimum- Patient: Or- Doctor: -this is sort of the only chance we have of getting it right now. text: Family Member: So would you suggest that he goes and see Dr. ____ uh when he’s scheduled or; now tomorrow he’s going to see - Patient: Another urologist. Doctor: And within that few days it had already gotten worse and because your kidney function was bad, that makes you have nausea and then you sort of – Patient: Right. Doctor: They come in, which, and you know when they looked at your picture um it really was where this was all started — that’s the problem because you can tell just by them just having to put a catheter in, that uh once your bladder gets empty and kidney functions get better. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh yeah so those are issues we have to talk about whether or not there is any role for radiation even though that’s not going to fix the big problem. text: Family Member: Aside from hormones. Healthcare Professional: So they stay on the hormones. Family Member: Oh. Healthcare Professional: So he stays on the hormones but then we add to it. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Either a second-line hormone like he was talking about that they’re looking at this trial using it earlier. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Or - Doctor: There are six drugs that have been approved by the FDA right now specifically for hormone-resistant prostate cancer. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Two of those six are chemos. One is immunotherapy, one is a bone-targeted therapy for bone metastases and two are pills. So there are six drugs in addition to the conventional, old-fashioned hormone therapy that we only use if the cancer becomes hormone-resistant. Healthcare Professional: And there are other ones in development right now.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
